fields.title: ECB Policy Rates
fields.content:
ECB at a Glance

  • Established in 1998, the ECB is the monetary authority of the Eurozone.
  • Its mandate centres on price stability (2% inflation target).
  • Since October 2008, the ECB has shifted from a scarce-reserve corridor to a floor system.
  • Its policy stance is transmitted through three rates: DF, MRO, and MLF.

Historical Cycles

[CHART1]

1. 1999-2000 ΓÇô First tightening after euro launch

ECB hikes from 2.5% to 4.75% as euro-area growth accelerates, oil prices surge, money/credit grow fast and the euro is weak. Goal: establish anti-inflation credibility and contain medium-term inflation risks.

2. 2001-2003 ΓÇô Dot-com bust and cautious cuts

ECB cuts from 4.75% to 2% as dot-com crash, global slowdown and 9/11 hit demand. Moves slower than the Fed because headline inflation is still pushed up by oil/tax effects.

3. 2003-2005 ΓÇô Low and flat ΓÇ£GoldilocksΓÇ¥

Main refi held at 2%. Growth moderate, inflation near 2%, no acute financial stress. ECB sees this as a suitably accommodative, stable stance.

4. 2005-2007 ΓÇô Pre-crisis normalisation

ECB hikes from 2% to 4% as growth is strong, oil and commodities rise, credit and money expand, and inflation runs above target. Aim: prevent overheating and de-anchoring of inflation expectations.

5. 2008-2009 ΓÇô Global Financial Crisis

After a last hike to 4.25% in July 2008, ECB slashes to 1% after Lehman and deep recession. Launches full-allotment LTROs and bond purchases to stabilise banks, credit and inflation.

6. 2010-2011 ΓÇô Sovereign crisis and policy mistake

ECB raises rates twice to 1.5% in 2011 on above-target inflation, while sovereign crisis in periphery explodes (Greece, Ireland, Portugal, then Italy and Spain later); partially offsets via SMP bond buying. Quickly reverses hikes as crisis worsens ΓÇô widely judged a mistake.

7. 2012-2014 ΓÇô Draghi, OMT, forward guidance, NIRP

ΓÇ£Whatever it takesΓÇ¥ and OMT backstop sovereigns and reduce fragmentation. ECB cuts rates to ~0, introduces forward guidance, then NIRP and targeted LTROs to fight recession and deflation risk.

8. 2015-2018 ΓÇô QE and prolonged ultra-easy policy

ECB runs large-scale APP (QE), keeps main refi at 0 and depo down to ΓÇô0.40%, plus TLTROs. Growth improves but inflation is still weak, so net purchases only stop at end-2018; rates remain at the lower bound.

9. 2019-2021 ΓÇô Renewed easing + COVID shock

2019: depo cut to ΓÇô0.50%, QE restarted, stronger forward guidance and reserve tiering as inflation undershoots. 2020ΓÇô21: COVID recession ΓåÆ PEPP and massive TLTROs while keeping rates at 0 / ΓÇô0.50% to prevent financial and deflationary spiral.

10. 2022-2023 ΓÇô Fastest hiking cycle

Post-COVID + energy shock push inflation into double digits. ECB ends net purchases and hikes from ΓÇô0.50% to 4% on the depo rate (July 2022ΓÇôSept 2023) to re-anchor inflation expectations despite weak growth.

11. From 2024 ΓÇô Disinflation and cautious easing

Inflation falls back towards target and growth is soft. From June 2024, ECB starts cutting from very restrictive levels and signals a gradual, data-dependent easing path to avoid over-tightening.

fields.title: template
fields.content:
Introduction

[CHART1] [CHART2]

Long-Term Policy Rate Timeline

Structural Policy Cycles (1999ΓÇô2025)

1. Pre-GFC Normalisation (1999ΓÇô2007)

[CHART2]

5. Normalisation Attempt (2024ΓÇôpresent)

With inflation trending down, the ECB is transitioning toward a normalisation phase. Forward guidance remains cautious, with decisions fully data-dependent and aligned with medium-term inflation dynamics.

ECB Policy Tools

  • Main Refinancing Operations (MRO) ΓÇô the central policy rate steering short-term liquidity.
  • Deposit Facility Rate ΓÇô the effective floor for Eurozone money markets.
  • Marginal Lending Facility ΓÇô the ceiling of the interest-rate corridor.
  • TLTRO / LTRO programmes ΓÇô long-term liquidity tools used extensively after 2011.
  • APP & PEPP ΓÇô balance-sheet tools for asset purchases during disinflationary periods.
  • Forward Guidance ΓÇô qualitative signalling introduced post-2011.

fields.title: gpt prompt
fields.content: For each concept i shared with you I'd like you to complement this (XXX1, XXX2, and XXX3) XXX3 XXX1 represent the full word, if there is no full word (meaning that I've already gave you the full word), XXX1 will be equal to XXX3 XXX2 represent the definition, very concise, sharp, clear, but be careful, exhaustive and perfectly formulated. XXX3 represent the element directly taken from the list I gave you you put the element betwen span Example: if I share you with a list of 2 concepts: Forward Guidance and LTRO, you should return LTRO Forward Guidance

fields.title: Fed Policy Rates
fields.content:
Fed at a Glance

  • Established in 1913, the Fed is the central bank of the United States.
  • Its dual mandate targets price stability (2% inflation goal) and maximum employment.
  • Since October 2008, the Fed has shifted from a scarce-reserve corridor to a floor system.
  • The Fed steers overnight rates through two administered tools: IORB and ON RRP.
  • Other relevant rates: FFTR (FFTRLΓÇôFFTRU) and DPCREDIT.

Historical Cycles

[CHART1]

1. 1999ΓÇô2000 ΓÇô Pre-dot-com tightening

Fed hikes from 4.75% to 6.5% as growth booms, labor markets tighten, and inflation risks rise. Aim: preempt overheating and asset bubbles.

2. 2001ΓÇô2003 ΓÇô Post-crash easing

Cuts from 6.5% to 1% after dot-com bust, 2001 recession, and 9/11. Inflation slows, unemployment rises. Introduces early forward guidance; flags deflation risk.

3. 2004ΓÇô2006 ΓÇô Normalization in housing boom

Raises rates steadily from 1% to 5.25% in 17 steps as credit and housing surge. Goal: withdraw stimulus and anchor expectations.

4. 2007ΓÇô2008 ΓÇô Crisis and ZIRP

Cuts rapidly from 5.25% to 0ΓÇô0.25% amid subprime meltdown and systemic collapse. Launches QE, emergency lending, and interest on reserves.

5. 2009ΓÇô2015 ΓÇô ZIRP, QE, and guidance

Keeps rates at 0ΓÇô0.25% for 7 years. Runs QE1ΓÇô3, sharpens forward guidance, and transitions to floor system using IOER and ON RRP.

6. 2015ΓÇô2018 ΓÇô Liftoff and runoff

Liftoff in Dec 2015 as labor market tightens and inflation approaches 2%. Starts runoff. Controls rates via IOER and ON RRP.

7. 2019 ΓÇô Insurance cuts and repo stress

Cuts 3 times to 1.5% amid trade tensions and weak inflation. Repo market dislocations prompt renewed liquidity injections.

8. 2020ΓÇô2021 ΓÇô COVID shock and QE infinity

Returns to 0ΓÇô0.25%, launches unlimited QE and broad credit backstops. Shifts to outcome-based guidance and adopts FAIT.

9. 2022ΓÇô2023 ΓÇô Inflation fight

Hikes from 0.25% to 5.5% in record time as inflation spikes. Ends QE, begins QT, and prioritizes price stability.

10. 2024ΓÇô2025 ΓÇô Disinflation and recalibration

With inflation easing, Fed cuts cautiously from mid-2024. By late 2025, rates fall to 3.75ΓÇô4.00%. Easing remains gradual and conditional.

fields.title: Key Global Policy Rates
fields.content:
Reading Notes

  • Focus on 9 key central banks only: Fed, ECB, BoJ, BoE, PBoC, SNB, BoC, RBA, Norges.
  • ON MM rates are used as policy rate proxies.

ON MM Rate Profiles

[CHART1]

Γ₧ñ Structurally low and stable SW/JP

  • JP has fought deflation for decades, from the post-bubble collapse (1990s) and weak demographics.
  • SW has fought the strong-CHF problem for decades, caused by persistent current-account surpluses, safe-haven inflows, and lower inflation than peers.

Γ₧ñ Unsynchronized and oscillating CN

  • CN runs scarce-reserve corridor to actively manage domestic liquidity and credit, because QE-style excess reserves would amplify leverage and bubble risks in ChinaΓÇÖs bank-dominated, real-estate-dependent system, unlike DM floor where deeper capital markets can better absorb such risks.

[CHART2]

Γ₧ñ Clear upward slope

    • Higher-rate regimes exhibit higher realized volatility.

    Γ₧ñ DM cluster vs CN/JP outliers

    • Most rates are mutually correlated except CN/JP, reflecting their idiosyncratic regimes.

    [CHART3]

    Γ₧ñ Post-2008 DM regime shifts

    • Most DM CBs shift from scarce-reserve corridor to abundant-reserve floor, visible in the collapse of ON MM rate volatility.

    Γ₧ñ Alternative regimes (JP/CN)

    • JP: ZIRP/NIRP + YCC, maintaining rates at or near 0% and long-term yields capped by fixed-rate BoJ operations.
    • CN: Volatile scarce-reserve corridor, where overnight spikes reflect intentional and frequent liquidity fine-tuning by the PBoC.

    Historical Cycles

    [CHART4]
    5-day moving average of ON MM rates across countries.

    1. 1999ΓÇô2000 ΓÇö HIKING Late-cycle tech boom

    Strong US growth + asset bubble ΓåÆ broad DM tightening.

    2. 2001ΓÇô2003 ΓÇö EASING Dotcom + 9/11 recession

    Demand slumps ΓåÆ coordinated DM rate cuts.

    3. 2004ΓÇô2007 ΓÇö HIKING Housing / credit / commodity boom

    Overheating + rising inflation ΓåÆ synchronized tightening.

    4. 2008ΓÇô2009 ΓÇö EASING GFC

    Systemic collapse ΓåÆ emergency cuts to zero + QE.

    5. 2010ΓÇô2011 ΓÇö HIKING Temporary commodity inflation

    Oil shock (>$100) ΓåÆ short, failed tightening attempt.

    6. 2012ΓÇô2015 ΓÇö EASING Euro crisis + deflation risk

    ZLB for G3 ΓåÆ forward guidance, QE, and other balance-sheet tools.

    7. 2016ΓÇô2019 ΓÇö HIKING US-led, mild global tightening

    Fed normalises; others stay dovish ΓåÆ partial divergence.

    8. 2020ΓÇô2021 ΓÇö EASING COVID crisis

    Fastest synchronized DM rate cuts in modern history + QE.

    9. 2022ΓÇô2023 ΓÇö HIKING Inflation shock

    Strongest tightening since the 1970s.

    10. 2024ΓÇôNow ΓÇö EASING Disinflation

    Inflation moderates; growth softens ΓåÆ DM tilt back toward cuts.


    [CHART5]
    $$\text{Hybrid MAD} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n} |x_i - \text{median}(x)| \quad \text{where } x_i \text{ are ON MM rates across countries.}$$

    ≡ƒö╡ Convergence

    1. 2001 ΓÇô Dotcom Bust ΓåÆ coordinated easing.
    2. 2009ΓÇô2010 ΓÇô GFC ΓåÆ universal zero-rate policy.
    3. 2020ΓÇô2022 ΓÇô COVID ΓåÆ synchronized emergency cuts.

    ≡ƒö┤ Divergence

    1. 2002 ΓÇô Fed kept cutting post-9/11; ECB stayed cautious.
    2. Late 2008 ΓÇô US crisis hit first, Fed cut fast; ECB lagged, focused on inflation
    3. 2011 ΓÇô ECB hiked prematurely (mistakenly); others held or eased.
    4. 2023ΓÇôNow ΓÇô Inflation hit unevenly, itΓÇÖs the stacking of multiple asymmetric shocks (energy, trade, fiscal, labor, housing).

    Mechanics of Policy Rate Transmission

    Γ₧¥ Price of Credit Channel

    Policy rate Γåô ΓåÆ money-market rates Γåô ΓåÆ banksΓÇÖ funding costs Γåô ΓåÆ lending rates Γåô ΓåÆ price of credit Γåô ΓåÆ demand for credit Γåæ ΓåÆ borrowing Γåæ ΓåÆ consumption Γåæ, investment Γåæ

    Γ₧¥ Credit-Supply Channel

    Policy rate Γåô ΓåÆ money-market rates Γåô ΓåÆ banksΓÇÖ funding costs Γåô ΓåÆ banksΓÇÖ willingness to lend Γåæ ΓåÆ credit supply Γåæ ΓåÆ consumption Γåæ, investment Γåæ

    Γ₧¥ Returns-On-Savings Channel

    Policy rate Γåô ΓåÆ money-market rates Γåô ΓåÆ yield on savings accounts Γåô ΓåÆ consumption Γåæ, investment Γåæ

    Γ₧¥ Asset-Price Channel

    Policy rate Γåô ΓåÆ money-market rates Γåô ΓåÆ risk-free rate Γåô ΓåÆ discount rate Γåô ΓåÆ present value of cash flows Γåæ ΓåÆ asset valuations Γåæ ΓåÆ bonds Γåæ (yields Γåô), equities Γåæ, and real estate Γåæ ΓåÆ

    • wealth Γåæ ΓåÆ consumption Γåæ
    • cost of capital Γåô ΓåÆ investment Γåæ
    • collateral values Γåæ ΓåÆ leverage capacity Γåæ ΓåÆ credit Γåæ
    • borrower net worth Γåæ ΓåÆ credit risk Γåô ΓåÆ credit availability Γåæ ΓåÆ credit Γåæ

    Γ₧¥ Exchange-Rate Channel

    Policy rate Γåô ΓåÆ capital inflows Γåô, capital outflows Γåæ ΓåÆ currency depreciation ΓåÆ exports Γåæ, import prices Γåæ (imported inflation Γåæ)

    Γ₧¥ Expectations Channel

    Policy rate Γåô + dovish communication ΓåÆ change expectations about future short rates, inflation, and economic conditions ΓåÆ

    • bonds Γåæ ΓåÆ long-term yields Γåô
    • risky assets Γåæ ΓåÆ equities Γåæ, real estate Γåæ
    • borrowing Γåæ ΓåÆ credit demand & supply Γåæ
    • consumption Γåæ, investment Γåæ
